coredata.dc:title: Suppressing toxic intermediates during photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate by controlling adsorption modes
coredata.dc:creator: Huang, Yingping
Li, Zhangli
Yao, Kun
Chen, Chuncheng
Deng, Chaoyuan
Fang, Yanfen
Li, Ruiping
Tian, Hailin
coredata.dc:description: The increasing presence of glyphosate has raised concerns about its potential impact on the environment and human health. The oxidative degradation of glyphosate during biotic and abiotic pathways usually leads to the formation of the toxic and persistent intermediates aminomethylphosphonic acid (AMPA). In this work, we report that the formation of AMPA during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate can be determined by its adsorption modes on the photocatalyst. The maximum accumulation of AMPA reached 31% on TiO2 photocatalyst. However, the formation of AMPA was markedly suppressed in the presence of F– ions, while the production of inorganic species such as PO4 3– and NO3 – was largely enhanced. In situ attenuated total reflectance Fourier transforms infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy revealed that the glyphosate was adsorbed on surface of TiO2 by its phosphate and carboxylate groups, while the adsorption site was changed to its amine group in the presence of F– ions. Such a change in the adsorption mode of glyphosate would facilitate the C–N bonds cleavage in glyphosate molecules, and inhibit the formation of AMPA, which makes the degradation of glyphosate go along a less toxic degradation pathway. The present study reveals a new relationship between the degradation pathway and the adsorption mode of glyphosate, which may also be helpful in other systems of abiotic degradation of glyphosate.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para:
(a) Kinetics of glyphosate degradation by TiO2, F−+TiO2, and direct photolysis; (b) Formation of AMPA; (c) Formation of PO4 3 , and (d) Formation of NO3
on TiO2 (black line) and F
+TiO2 (red line) at different time. Reaction conditions: Glyphosate concentration = 500 μmol·L−1; TiO2 = 0.2 g·L− 1; F
concentration = 6 mmol·L−1; pH~3.2; room temperature and 300 W UV irradiation. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

The accumulated AMPA in different initial concentration of glyphosate between TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst. Reaction conditions: TiO2 = 0.2 g·L−1; F– concentration = 6 mmol·L−1; pH~3.2; room temperature and 300 W UV irradiation.

ESI( –)-MS monitoring of glyphosate degradation products in (a) the TiO2/UV photocatalyst system and (b) the F
+TiO2/UV photocatalyst system at different reaction time.

In situ ATR-FTIR spectra of (a) adsorbed glyphosate in pure water on TiO2 film and (b) the detailed FTIR peaks from 860 cm−1 to 1760 cm−1 (the area of red dash box in Fig. 3a). In situ ATR-FTIR spectra of (c) adsorbed glyphosate in F− ions solution on TiO2 film and (d) the corresponding spectra from 860 cm−1 to 1760 cm−1 (the area of red dash box in Fig. 3c). The spectra were showed at 0.5, 1, 10, 20, 30, 60, and 120 min. Adsorption conditions: Glyphosate concentration = 500 μmol·L−1; F− concentration = 6 mmol·L−1; pH~3.2 and room temperature.
The optimized adsorption configuration of glyphosate on (a) bare TiO2 and (b) F-covered TiO2 surface by ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation.

The total density of states (TDOS) and partial density of states (PDOS) on different atoms for glyphosate on (a–d) bare TiO2 and (e–h) F−+TiO2 surface. The electron density difference for glyphosate adsorbed on (i) TiO2 and (j) F−+TiO2 surface. Yellow represents electron accumulation and cyan denotes electron depletion, and the unit of isosurface values is 0.004 electron Bohr−3. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
Two pathways for the degradation of glyphosate.

head.ce:title: Suppressing toxic intermediates during photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate by controlling adsorption modes

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The increasing presence of glyphosate has raised concerns about its potential impact on the environment and human health. The oxidative degradation of glyphosate during biotic and abiotic pathways usually leads to the formation of the toxic and persistent intermediates aminomethylphosphonic acid (AMPA). In this work, we report that the formation of AMPA during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate can be determined by its adsorption modes on the photocatalyst. The maximum accumulation of AMPA reached 31% on TiO2 photocatalyst. However, the formation of AMPA was markedly suppressed in the presence of F– ions, while the production of inorganic species such as PO4 3– and NO3 – was largely enhanced. In situ attenuated total reflectance Fourier transforms infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy revealed that the glyphosate was adsorbed on surface of TiO2 by its phosphate and carboxylate groups, while the adsorption site was changed to its amine group in the presence of F– ions. Such a change in the adsorption mode of glyphosate would facilitate the C–N bonds cleavage in glyphosate molecules, and inhibit the formation of AMPA, which makes the degradation of glyphosate go along a less toxic degradation pathway. The present study reveals a new relationship between the degradation pathway and the adsorption mode of glyphosate, which may also be helpful in other systems of abiotic degradation of glyphosate.

The formation of AMPA during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate can be determined by its adsorption modes on the photocatalyst. In situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy revealed that the glyphosate was adsorbed on surface of TiO2 by its phosphate and carboxylate groups, while the adsorption site was changed to its amine group in the presence of F– ions. DFT calculation was further used to elucidate the different adsorption modes.
ga1

ce:section.ce:para: Glyphosate (N-phosphonomethyl glycine) belongs to the class of organophosphate compounds (OPCs). As a nonselective, postemergence herbicide, glyphosate is the worldwide commonly used on agricultural fields [1,2]. The worldwide application of glyphosate has resulted in its ubiquitous presence in soil and aquatic environments, which has been caused continuing public concerns about its safety [3,4]. Particularly, its degradation intermediate AMPA was proven to be more persistent, more mobile and more toxic than glyphosate itself under environmentally realistic conditions [5,6]. Therefore, how to avoid the formation of AMPA during the degradation of glyphosate is an important issue to eliminate the environmental effect of glyphosate.

Glyphosate molecule contains a glycine-like moiety and a phosphonomethyl end ( Scheme 1). During degradation of glyphosate, cleavages of four bonds are involved to determine the degradation intermediates. Besides the formation of AMPA by breaking the C–C bond or C–N bond in the glycine-like side (the AMPA pathway), another pathway involves the cleavage of a C–P or C–N bond of the phosphonomethyl end, which would lead to the production of sarcosine or glycine (the sarcosine pathway) [1]. Therefore, the preferential cleavage of the phosphonate adjacent C–N bond is obtained to form comparatively benign glycine or to release of orthophosphate as degradation products, which has both scientific and environmental significance in less toxic glyphosate degradation pathways.

During both biotic and abiotic degradation of glyphosate, the AMPA pathway is usually reported to be the dominant degradation of mechanism, while the sarcosine is less commonly detected as a product [7–9]. For example, in the soil-water system, AMPA started to accumulate and was found to be 3–6 times more resistant than glyphosate against degradation by soil microorganisms [7]. The existence of AMPA and glyoxylic acid and the absence of sarcosine indicated that the glyphosate degradation by wet air oxidation followed the mechanism of C−N bond cleavage in the glycine-like side [8]. Additionally, in iron oxides/UV or manganese oxide system, an abiotic degradation of glyphosate would follow the sarcosine pathway or glycine pathway, rather than the AMPA pathway [1,10]. Therefore, the degradation of glyphosate requires better understanding of the roles of additional but yet unknown factors on the preference of the bond cleavage.

Due to the strong coordinative ability of the carboxylate and phosphate groups, glyphosate tends to adsorb on the surface of metal oxides through its carboxylate and phosphate groups [11,12]. It was reported that the preference of C–P or C–N bond cleavage during glyphosate oxidation on manganese oxide vary with changing glyphosate/manganese oxide ratios, which suggests that the adsorption of glyphosate may influence the product distribution during its oxidation on manganese oxide [13]. Although the radical properties of TiO2-based photocatalysis, which has been reported to be efficient for degradation of glyphosate [11,14], make it difficult to control the degradation pathway of pollutants, there are successful reports that modulate the product distribution during TiO2 photocatalysis by surface modification. The commercial TiO2 (P25) is a widely used adsorption and photocatalyst material. Meanwhile, it is known that P25 TiO2 consists two crystalline phases of rutile and anatase. The surface of both phases has exposed Ti sties, on which the F– ions can be strongly adsorbed. For example, the surface fluorination of TiO2 (P25) can change the adsorption mode of Rhodamine B, a zwitterionic dye with the anionic carboxylic (–COOH) and cationic dimethylamido (–NEt2) groups, from –COOH adsorption to the –NEt2 adsorption, and consequently the degradation pathway of the dye was also changed totally [15].

In this study, we investigated the relationship between the adsorption of glyphosate and its photocatalytic degradation pathway on TiO2 by using F– to control the interaction mode. We found that the relative dominance of AMPA versus sarcosine pathways during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate is able to be controlled by its adsorption on TiO2. The presence of F– markedly depressed the formation of AMPA and enhanced the production of inorganic ions. The in situ ATR-FTIR spectroscopy and Density Function Theory (DFT) calculation were further used to elucidate the different adsorption modes and degradation pathways. The insights gained from this work contribute to a better understanding in the selective photocatalytic process of TiO2 and the safely removal of glyphosate.

Commercial TiO2 (P25), which consists of 80% anatase and 20% rutile, was used as a photocatalyst obtained from Degussa Company, Germany. The fluoride ions were adsorbed on the surface of TiO2 photocatalyst (F–+TiO2). The standard chemicals, such as glyphosate (99.5%), AMPA (97%), glycine (98.5%), and sarcosine (98%) were purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). All other reagents were analytical grade and were used as received without any further purification. The aqueous solutions in this study were prepared by using deionized water.

The detailed characterization of TiO2 and ( F–+TiO2) is given in the Supporting Information. The XRD pattern (Fig. S1) of TiO2 showed a multi-phase structure composed of anatase and rutile. For F–+TiO2, the similar XRD pattern was observed. The morphology of photocatalysts before and after F– adsorption was characterized by SEM (JEOL, Japan). As shown in Fig. S2, there is no significant difference in the morphology of photocatalysts before and after F– adsorption, indicating that the covering of F– ions does not change the structure and morphology of TiO2. The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst are shown in Fig. S3. The inset of Fig. S3 shows the plot of (αhν)2 vs. photoenergy, and the band gap of TiO2 and F
+TiO2 photocatalyst is calculated to 3.24 eV and 3.15 eV, respectively. It indicates that the band structure of TiO2 has little changed after the adsorption of F
ions. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a VG ESCALA-B220i-XL (Thermo Scientific, UK) with an Al Kα X-ray source at a residual gas pressure below 10−8 Pa. And all binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak (284.8 eV).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic and electron spin resonance (ESR) experiments
ce:section.ce:para:
To investigate the composition of intermediate products and degradation pathways, glyphosate degradation experiments were carried out with TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst. Briefly, the suspension (40 mL) containing TiO2 (0.2 g·L−1) and glyphosate (300–1000 μmol·L−1) was thoroughly mixed and magnetically stirred. The adsorption-desorption equilibrium could be obtained after 30 min (Fig. S4). For the F
+TiO2 system, 6 mmol·L−1 of F
ion was present in the suspensions. The photodegradation of glyphosate was carried out in an XPA-7 photoreactor (Nanjing, China) with a 300 W mercury lamp as light source. Each reactor was continually stirred to maintain a uniform distribution of reactants at room temperature. Sample aliquots were taken from the reactor at given time. All experiments were conducted in triplicates. The samples were separated by centrifugation and filtration (0.22 µm hydrophilic polyethersulfone filter) for the ensuing analyses. ESR experiments were performed to identify by using a Bruker ER200-SRC spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) with a 100 W mercury lamp. ESR signals were recorded after adding dimethyl pyridine N-oxide (DMPO) for ∙OH and O2 •−. As shown in Fig. S5, DMPO∙-OH and DMPO∙-OOH signals can be observed in TiO2 and F
+TiO2 photocatalysts.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Analysis of glyphosate and its degradation products
ce:section.ce:para: Dionex ICS-2100 ion chromatography (IC) was used to determine the concentration of glyphosate and the anion species of degradation products. Eluent was 30 mmol·L−1 KOH at a flow-rate of 1.0 mL·min−1. Injection volume of samples was 25 μL. Data were acquired by using Chromeleon 7 chromatography data system. The linearity of mineral ions such as PO4 3– and NO3 – was carried out at 10–500 μmol·L−1 by IC (Figs. S6 and S7).

To quantify glyphosate and its major degradation products, such as AMPA, samples collected at given irradiation time were analyzed by Waters 2690 high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with PDA detector and an Acclaim 120, C18 column (4.6 × 250 mm, 5 µm particle size). The derivatization prior to the analysis was carried out using 9-fluorenylmethyl chloroformate (FMOC) [1,16]. The linearity of HPLC derivatization method was detected the standard chemicals including glyphosate and AMPA from 10 to 1000 μmol·L−1 (Fig. S8). The limit of detection for glyphosate and AMPA in this work was 10 μmol·L−1. The detailed HPLC method is given in the Supporting Information.

The real-time detection of glyphosate degradation intermediates was performed using an Agilent 6310 ion trap mass spectrometer (MS) by fully scanning from mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) 40–140 in the negative ion mode. The reaction samples were analyzed by direct infusion into the electrospray ionization (ESI) source via a syringe pump at a flow-rate of 200 μL·min−1. ESI conditions were as follows: heated capillary temperature, 350 °C; sheath gas (N2) flow rate, 10 L·min−1; spray voltage, 4.5 kV. The relative intensity of the mass spectrum can be used to determine the relative concentration for the same product.

To investigate the time-resolved adsorption sites of glyphosate on TiO2, a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a liquid-nitrogen cooled MCT detector was used in the ATR-FTIR experiments. A horizontal ATR cell (PIKE Technology) with a 45° ZnSe crystal was applied for static and in situ flow cell ATR-FTIR spectrum [12,17]. TiO2 suspensions (3.3 g·L−1) and glyphosate stock solution (5000 μmol·L−1) were prepared with deionized water. Thin film of TiO2 was prepared with TiO2 suspensions onto the ZnSe crystal and drying in natural environment. Water and F– ions solution (6 mmol·L−1) were used as the solvent to investigate adsorption sites at the glyphosate/TiO2 interface. The equilibrium background spectra were recorded after adding solvent (1.35 mL) to the flow cell between TiO2 thin film and each solution. Finally, the time-resolved ATR-FTIR spectra were collected continuously for 120 min using the TiO2– solvent spectra as background when the stock glyphosate solution of 0.15 mL was added in the equilibrated system.

DFT calculations were implemented by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [18–21] at the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) level with the PBE exchange-correlation functional [22]. Projector augmented wave (PAW) method [23,24] was performed to model the ion-electron interaction. To better describe the dispersion interaction, Grimme’s D3 correction with the Becke-Johnson damping was adopted [25,26]. Since Ti atoms contain strongly correlated 3d electrons, a typical U – J value of 4.0 eV was selected [27,28]. An energy cutoff of 400 eV was used for the plane-wave basis set, and the Gaussian smearing method was applied, with the σ value chosen to be 0.2 eV, unless otherwise noted.

For the lattice optimization of anatase TiO2, 11 × 11 × 11 Gamma-centered Monkhorst-Pack k-points sampling was used [29], with an energy cutoff of 800 eV for the plane-wave basis set. Electronic energy convergence criterion was set to be 10−6 eV, and structures were optimized until the maximum force on the atoms was smaller than 0.01 eV/Å. Besides, the σ value was chosen to be 0.05 eV. The optimized lattice parameters were a = b = 3.83 Å, c = 9.59 Å.

The anatase TiO2 (101) surface was modeled by a three-layer slab. A 4 × 1 supercell along [010] and [101̅] directions with a vacuum layer of 15 Å was used. The supercell contained 180 atoms and only the gamma point was included for the sampling of Brillouin zone when geometric structures were optimized. To obtain an adsorption configuration of glyphosate with a relatively low energy, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation was running for 8 ps in the canonical (NVT) ensemble, with a time step of 1 fs. The temperature of the supercell was maintained steady at 350 K employing a Nosé−Hoover thermostat [30,31]. Then, the geometric structure optimization was performed, with structures relaxed until the maximum force on the atoms smaller than 0.03 eV/Å. The electronic energy convergence criterion was set to be 10−5 eV. Subsequently, the 3 × 2 × 1 Gamma-centered Monkhorst-Pack k-points sampling were accepted for the single-point calculations to get refined density of states (DOS). Moreover, the F-terminated (101) surface was constructed by covering the above surface with 16 dissociated HF molecules, and the computational parameters were same as the anatase TiO2 (101) surface.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Glyphosate degradation products during the photocatalytic process
ce:section.ce:para:
The negligible degradation of glyphosate was observed under UV irradiation in the absence of photocatalyst ( Fig. 1a). While TiO2 was used as the photocatalyst, the degradation of glyphosate was quite rapid, and about 83.4% of glyphosate was removed in 5 h irradiation. In the presence of F–, the overall degradation was enhanced to some extent and the degradation rate became 87.8% within 5 h. The most remarkable difference between TiO2 and F–+TiO2 systems comes from the formation of the toxic AMPA intermediate. As shown in Fig. 1b, on bare TiO2, the maximum AMPA concentration, appearing after 2 h of irradiation, was 50 μmol·L−1. At this point, about 162 μmol·L−1 glyphosate was degraded, which means the yield for AMPA is 31%. After the maximum, a slow decay in the concentration of AMPA was observed. For F–+TiO2 photocatalyst, the accumulation of AMPA was markedly depressed. The maximum concentration of AMPA during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate was 24 μmol·L−1 and the corresponding yield is about 12%. In addition, the decay of AMPA in the presence of F
was also quite rapid after the maximum.

For F−+TiO2 photocatalyst, more inorganic PO4 3– and NO3 – anions were released during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate (Fig. 1c). For example, after 5 h irradiation, the concentration of formed NO3 – was 27 μmol·L−1 in TiO2 photocatalyst, while 95 μmol·L−1 of NO3 – was formed in the presence of F
, which is about 3.5 times higher than that of TiO2 photocatalyst (Fig. 1d). The detected NO2
of F
+TiO2 photocatalyst was also obviously higher than that of TiO2 photocatalyst by IC (Fig. S9), indicating that the oxidation of amine groups may be from NO2
to NO3 –. Many intermediates and products can be formed during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate on both TiO2 and F
+TiO2 photocatalyst. However, only AMPA, glycine, inorganic PO4 3 –, NO2
and NO3 – ions were detected by HPLC and IC. For the formation of PO4 3–, it is evident that the phosphorus in glyphosate is dominantly transformed to AMPA and inorganic PO4 3– (accounting for more than 90% of the parent glyphosate). By contrast, for fate of the nitrogen element during the photocatalytic degradation, besides the detected AMPA, NO2
and NO3 – ions, there should be larger amount of other N-containing products such as NH4 +, which were not analyzed in the present study. We noted that orthophosphate dominated over primary amines (the sum of AMPA and glycine) in TiO2-based photocatalyst, while the higher rate and extent of primary amines compared to that of orthophosphate production appeared in the degradation of glyphosate by manganese oxide/UV and birnessite [1,13]. The results indicate that more amine and phosphate groups of glyphosate are mineralized to inorganic PO4 3 and NO3
ions in the F
+TiO2 photocatalyst, which is consistent with the depressed formation of AMPA.

At the different F− concentrations, there is litter influence for the degradation of glyphosate for F–+TiO2 photocatalyst (Fig. S10a). As shown in Fig. S10b, the accumulated AMPA is depressed about 30% in comparison of TiO2 when the concentration of F− is 3 mM. It is demonstrated that the surface of TiO2 may not be covered by a small amount of F− ions. However, the initial concentration of F− is 9 mM, the formation of AMPA cannot further decrease. Therefore, the optimized concentration of F− is 6 mM during the degradation of glyphosate. All these observations indicate that the presence of F– changes the degradation pathway of glyphosate and its intermediates in TiO2 photocatalyst. It is well known that TiO2 has the excellent thermal stability and photostability. Since the lattice structure and phase composition are similar during the adsorption of F– ions on the surface of TiO2 (Fig. S1), the stability of F–+TiO2 photocatalyst will be retained. Moreover, the concentration of F– ions (6 mmol·L−1) is much higher than that of the maximum generated PO4 3– (0.5 mmol·L−1). Therefore, the competitive adsorption between F– ions and PO4 3– can be ignored in the experimental condition.

Moreover, the suppression effect of the accumulated AMPA was more apparent in high concentration of glyphosate between TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst ( Fig. 2). When the concentration of glyphosate was increased to 1000 μmol·L−1, the maximum accumulation AMPA of TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst was 121 μmol·L−1 and 41 μmol·L−1, respectively. The suppression of AMPA is 52% in 500 μmol·L−1 glyphosate, while the inhibition rate of AMPA will increase to 66% in 1000 μmol·L−1 glyphosate. On the other hand, the amount of AMPA was 17 μmol·L−1 in 300 μmol·L−1 glyphosate, indicating that the formation of AMPA cannot be totally depressed for F
+TiO2 photocatalyst. Therefore, the photocatalytic mechanism of glyphosate between TiO2 and F
+TiO2 photocatalyst should be further investigated.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Real-time detection of glyphosate degradation products by MS spectroscopy
ce:section.ce:para: The reaction intermediates in TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst were further detected by directly injecting the reacted solution into ESI-MS. The MS spectra of samples collected at given time during the degradation of glyphosate are shown in Fig. 3. For TiO2 photocatalyst, the MS peak with m/z = 124, which is assigned to the N-methyl-aminomethylphosphonic acid (Me-AMPA), was found to the dominant intermediate, and AMPA with m/z = 110 was the second abundant product after irradiation of 1 h (Fig. 3a). At the irradiation of 3 h, AMPA became dominant over Me-AMPA, indicating that AMPA may be produced secondarily by demethylation from Me-AMPA. These results suggest that the decarboxylation reaction should dominate the first step for the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate on TiO2. Finally, the amount of Me-AMPA and AMPA was decreased with the irradiation after 3 h. PO4 3– anions became the dominant product, which can be demonstrated by the HPLC results in Fig. 1c. By contrast, the product distribution of glyphosate degradation was distinctly changed by adding fluoride ions on the surface of TiO2 photocatalyst. As shown in Fig. 3b, acetic acid (m/z = 59) became the major product in F–+TiO2 photocatalyst. Another intermediate, glycine (m/z = 74), appeared as the minor degradation product. Glycine could be detected by MS and HPLC, however, the amount of glycine was at or below detection limit in this study. It is evident that the formation of both the acetic acid and glycine involves the cleavage of C–N bonds during the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate. The amine group of glyphosate might be transformed into NO3 –, which is further confirmed by MS results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Identification adsorbed sites of glyphosate on TiO2 photocatalyst under different conditions
ce:section.ce:para: Glyphosate interacts with TiO2 photocatalyst surface through three polar functional groups of phosphonate, amine, and carboxylate [32], which in turn significantly influences the degradation pathway of glyphosate. ATR-FTIR spectra of glyphosate adsorbed on TiO2 photocatalyst were collected to gain an insight into the interaction affecting the photocatalytic mechanism. As shown in Fig. 4a, b, when glyphosate was added into the pure water solution on the TiO2 film, the bands at 1616 cm−1 from the asymmetric stretching vibration of carboxylate (ν COO − as) and at 1398, 1324 cm−1 (symmetric stretching vibration of carboxyl (ν COO − s) appeared [33], indicative of the adsorption of glyphosate by its carboxylate group (Fig. 4b). At the same time, the band at 1130 cm−1, which is attributed to the P＝O stretching vibration (νP＝O) in the phosphonate group, and the characteristic peaks of 1006 cm−1 and 1080 cm−1 (assigned to the P−O−Ti stretching vibration (ν P−O−Ti) were also observed [34], suggesting that the formation of glyphosate surface complexes by its phosphate groups on TiO2 (Fig. 4b). The possible glyphosate surface configurations were the mononuclear monodentate (MM) structure in the phosphonate group with or without proton [12]. The peaks of the phosphonate and carboxylate group were enhanced with the time from 0 to 120 min. Additionally, a negative peak at about 3120 cm−1 (Fig. 4a), which is assigned to the stretching vibration of O−H from surface hydroxyl group or water molecules [17], was also detected, concomitant with the appearance of the peaks from the carboxylate and phosphonate group, indicating that the substitution of surface hydroxyl groups or water molecules by carboxylate and phosphonate groups. It is demonstrated that the main adsorption sites of glyphosate were the phosphonate and carboxylate groups as chelating ligands on bare TiO2 photocatalyst. Such interaction mode originates from the strong coordination ability of the carboxylate and phosphate groups of glyphosate [34], which makes glyphosate to bind on the metal oxide by coordinating with surface metal sites through the carboxylate and phosphonate groups.

Intriguingly, in the presence of F−, the ATR-FTIR spectra were significantly changed. A broad and strong peak at 3100–3500 cm−1, which is the NH stretching vibration (νNH) in the amine group of glyphosate, appeared (Fig. 4c), while the peaks from the coordinated carboxylate and phosphonate groups was significantly suppressed (Fig. 4d). These ATR-FTIR results imply that the amine group is the dominant adsorption site between glyphosate and the adsorbed F
on TiO2 photocatalyst, which makes the CN bond of glyphosate more vulnerable [1,13]. The XPS analysis showed no obvious differences of Ti 2p and O 1s binding energy between TiO2 and F
+TiO2 photocatalyst except for the F 1s (Fig. S11), suggesting that F
ions covered or substituted on the surface of TiO2. The glyphosate-surface interaction on TiO2 photocatalyst, namely, the adsorption mode, was altered in the presence of F
ions. Together with all of the evidence above, we have concluded that the change of adsorption modes was an important reason for the different degradation pathways of glyphosate on the surface of TiO2 photocatalyst.

To shed light on the difference in the adsorption mode glyphosate on TiO2 and F-covered TiO2 surface, we investigated the adsorption configuration of glyphosate on these two surfaces by ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation. After placing the glyphosate on the bare TiO2 (101) surface, the geometric optimization following AIMD led to the adsorption of glyphosate on the Ti site by its phosphonate and carboxylate groups, as shown in Fig. 5a. Specifically, one of proton in the PO3H2– group is shifted to the amine group nitrogen atom, and the phosphonate is adsorbed on the Ti site through one of its oxygen atoms. The carboxylate interacts strongly with surface Ti atoms via one of its oxygen atoms. Moreover, the proton of the carboxylate is dissociated after the adsorption. On the surface of F–+TiO2, the surface Ti was covered by F– ions. To keep the electroneutrality of slab, protons were placed on the bridge oxygen adjacent to F– ions to form bridged hydroxyl groups. After the geometric optimization, the obtained adsorption configuration of glyphosate is much different from that on the bare TiO2 surface. First, both the phosphonate and carboxylate group become protonated (Fig. 5b); Second, the amine group adsorbs on the surface through two hydrogen bonds, one of which is on the bridge oxygen atom and the other is on the surface F atom; Third, because the surface Ti sites are occupied by F– ions, the oxygen atoms of the phosphonate and carboxylate group do not interact directly with the surface Ti sites any more. Instead, one of the oxygen atoms of the phosphonate group adsorbs on the hydrogen of bridged hydroxyl groups through hydrogen bond, and the hydrogen atoms of the phosphonate group can interact with the surface F atoms through hydrogen bond.

The different adsorption configurations of glyphosate could lead to distinct behaviors during the photocatalytic degradation. To show the difference in electronic structure between the adsorbed glyphosate on TiO2 and F–+TiO2, we compared their density of states (DOS) by using density functional theory + U (DFT + U). As shown in Fig. 6, on the surface of TiO2, partial density of states (PDOS) on carboxylate groups of the adsorbed glyphosate (Fig. 6c) is located at top of valence band (VB) of TiO2 (Fig. 6a), which consists dominantly of the 2p orbital of lattice O (Fig. 6b). However, the PDOS distribution of the amine group of glyphosate is quite weak at VB top (Fig. 6d). Therefore, the photoinduced valence band holes of TiO2 tend to be trapped at the carboxylate group, which would lead to the decarboxylation of glyphosate, as in the situation of Kolbe decarboxylation reaction [14]. On the surface of F
+TiO2, the density of states of the amine of glyphosate around the band edge becomes more positive than that the carboxylate group (Fig. 6g, h), which suggests that the amine moiety is more favorable to trap the photoinduced hole than the carboxylate group. The trapping hole by the amine moiety would result in the cleavage of the C–N bonds. The electron density difference for glyphosate adsorbed on TiO2 and F-covered TiO2 surface represents the electron transfer and the bond energy (Fig. 6i, j). After absorbing glyphosate on F
+TiO2, the electron density of the CN bonds was decreased, indicating that the cleavage of the CN bonds can be achieved due to the weak bond energy [35]. If the CN bonds broke at the amine group, the formation of AMPA would be avoided, which is consistent with the experimental results that the formation of less AMPA on the surface of F
+TiO2.

In this study, the photocatalytic degradation mechanism of glyphosate was proved in TiO2 and F–+TiO2 photocatalyst by quantifying intermediate products and identifying adsorption sites using HPLC, ESI-MS, ATR-FTIR and DFT calculation. The formation of AMPA was inhibited in photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate due to the changed adsorption mode. More benign intermediates and inorganic anions, such as acetic acid, PO4 3– and NO3 –, would be formed in the photocatalytic degradation of glyphosate for F–+TiO2 photocatalyst. This work revealed a new relationship between the degradation pathway and the adsorption mode of glyphosate. Overall, the preferential adsorption sites and the less accumulated AMPA in F–+TiO2 photocatalyst provided insights into the selective photocatalytic process of TiO2 and the safely removal of glyphosate.

Ruiping Li: Methodology, Writing – review & editing, Validation. Hailin Tian: Methodology, Writing – original draft, Data curation, Visualization.
